Regeneration after injury is not seen

questions.solution:
Differences between skeletal, cardiac and smooth muscles are as follows:

So Options A, B and C are true about smooth muscles and Option D is false.

Tag: Histology of muscles

Reference: I. B. Singh's Textbook of Human Histology, 10th Edition, Page Number -; 82

questions.text: Pseudostratified columnar epithelium with large microvilli is seen in which of the following structure?
questions.solution:
Pseudo stratified epithelium: it is not stratified but appears to be stratified . Cells are attached to basement membrane but of varying heights, it may also bear cilia, stereocilia and contain goblet cells


Option A) Auditory tube(Eustachian tube)- lined by non ciliated pseudostratified columnar epithelium

Option C) Ductus deferens(vas deferens)- lined by non ciliated pseudostratified columnar epithelium

Option D) Trachea- lined by ciliated  pseudostratified columnar epithelium

KEY TAKEAWAYS - pseudo stratified epithelium can be squamous or columnar based on its location and can be associated with cilia , stereocilia, goblet cells which help in motility, adhesion and mucous production respectively

Tag: Histology of epithelium

Reference: I. B. Singh's Textbook of Human Histology, 10th Edition, Page Number - 24, 25

• Descemet's membrane is seen in the cornea.

Option A) RETINA- has 10 layers and Descemet's membrane is not a part of retina

Option c) SCLERA- It is the outer 5\6 th of the eyeball, its opaque, thinnest at the insertion of extraocular muscles , thickest around optic nerve head

Option d) Iris - forms the anterior part of the uveal apparatus, separates anterior and posterior chamber , inflammation of iris leads to anterior uveitis

Tag: Histology of eyeball

Reference: I. B. Singh's Textbook of Human Histology, 10th Edition, Page Number - 289, 290, 291

questions.text: Holocrine manner of secretion is seen in which of the following gland?
questions.solution:
The manner in which their secretions are poured out of the cells:

  • Merocrine:
    • In most exocrine glands secretions are thrown out of the cells by a process of exocytosis.
    • The cell remaining intact, this manner of secretion is described as merocrine.
    • It is also called eccrine or epicrine.
    • Example: goblet cell (Option A) , sweat glands of palms and soles
  • Apocrine:
    • In some glands the apical parts of the cells are shed off to discharge the secretion, this manner of secretion is described as apocrine.
    • Example: atypical sweat glands (Option D), mammary glands (Option B)
  • Holocrine:
    • In some glands, the entire cell disintegrates while discharging its secretion.
    • This manner of discharging secretion is described as holocrine.
    • Example: sebaceous glands (Option C)

Tag: Histology of glands

Reference: I. B. Singh's Textbook of Human Histology, 10th Edition, Page Number - 30, 31

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of elastic cartilage?
questions.solution:
Types and examples of the cartilage:

KEYTAKEAWAYS -

HYALINE CARTILAGE - cells in group , matrix shiny and glassy, type 2 collagen, perichondrium present

ELASTIC CARTILAGE - cells in group , elastic fibres present, type 2 collagen, perichondrium present

FIBROUS CARTILAGE - cells in rows , bundles of collagen, type 1 collagen, perichondrium absent

Tag: Histology of cartilage

Reference: I. B. Singh's Textbook of Human Histology, 10th Edition, Page Number - 57

questions.text: Congenital anomaly results from failure of coils of the small intestine to return into abdominal cavity from their physiological herniation into extraembryonic coelom is known as:
questions.solution:
Congenital anomalies of umbilicus:

  • Exomphalos or omphalocele (Option D):
    • This anomaly results from failure of coils of the small intestine to return into abdominal cavity from their physiological herniation into extraembryonic celom during sixth to tenth week of IUL.
  • Congenital umbilical hernia (Option B):
    • In this anomaly, there is herniation of abdominal viscera through the weak umbilical opening (poorly closed umbilicus).
    • Clinically, it presents as a protrusion in the linea alba.
    • The contents are covered with peritoneum, subcutaneous tissue, and skin.
  • Gastroschisis (Option A):
    • In this anomaly, there is a linear defect in anterior abdominal wall through which abdominal contents herniate out.
    • It occurs lateral to the umbilicus, usually on to the right.
    • This defect is produced when lateral folds of embryo fail to fuse with each other around connecting stalk.
  • Raspberry red tumour (Option C):
    • Remnants of the vitellointestinal duct may form a tumour at the umbilicus.
    • Also known as cherry red tumour.

Tag: Development of digestive system

Reference: Textbook of Clinical Embryology by Vishram Singh, 3rd Edition page Number - 198

questions.text: Identify the nerve in the figure below:
questions.solution:
Figure is showing the nerves of pharyngeal arch:

  • The marked structure is nerve of third arch (Glossopharyngeal nerve)
  • Nerve of first arch:
    • Trigeminal nerve (maxillary and mandibular divisions) is the nerve of the first arch.
    • The first arch is also supplied by the chorda tympani nerve, a pretrematic branch of the facial nerve (the nerve of second arch).
  • Nerve of the second arch:
    • Facial nerve is the nerve of the second arch and supplies the motor branches to all the muscles derived from second arch.
  • Nerve of the third arch:
    • Glossopharyngeal nerve is the nerve of the third arch. Its motor component supplies stylopharyngeus muscle while its sensory component supplies mucous membrane of the pharynx.
  • Nerves of the fourth arch:
    • Superior laryngeal nerve, a branch of vagus nerve, is the nerve of the fourth arch.
    • It supplies cricothyroid muscle of the larynx.
  • Nerve of sixth arch:
    • Recurrent laryngeal nerve is nerve of sixth arch. It is also a branch of the vagus nerve.
    • It supplies rest of the intrinsic muscles of the larynx.

Derivatives of the pharyngeal arches:

Tag: Development of pharyngeal arches

Reference: Textbook of Clinical Embryology by Vishram Singh, 3rd Edition page Number - 151, 152

questions.text: Which of the following structures develops in ventral part of ventral mesogastrium?
questions.solution:
• The abdominal part of the foregut is suspended by mesenteries both ventrally and dorsally.
  • The ventral mesentery of the foregut is called the ventral mesogastrium, and the dorsal mesentery is called dorsal mesogastrium (gastrium means stomach)
  • The fate of ventral mesogastrium(pneumonic - Lesser FACT)
    • Lesser omentum
    • FAlciform ligament
    • Coronary ligament
    • Triangular ligament
  • The fate of the dorsal mesogastrium is as follows.
    • Gastrosplenic ligament
    • Lineorenal ligament
    • Gastrophrenic ligament
    • Greater omentum

Tag: Development of digestive system

Reference: Textbook of Clinical Embryology by Vishram Singh, 3rd Edition page Number - 192

questions.text: All of the followings are derivatives of mesoderm, EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Derivatives of three germ layers are as follow:

Option A - epithelium of vessels - lateral plate mesoderm

Option B - testes - intermediate mesoderm from genital ridge

Option C - adrenal medulla - NCC > ectoderm

Option D. - cartilages - paraxial medicine

Tag: Germ layers

Reference: Textbook of Clinical Embryology by Vishram Singh, 3rd Edition page Number - 76

questions.text: Which of the following part gives rise to development of floor of fossa ovalis?
questions.solution:
The development of interatrial septum:

  • It divides the primitive atrium into the right and left atria.
  • It is formed as under:
  • The interatrial septum is formed by two septa:
    • Septum primum and septum secundum.
  • Septum primum starts developing from the roof of the primitive atrial chamber a little to the left of the opening of sinus venosus.
    • It is crescent shaped and is present in an oblique plane.
    • It grows downward towards septum intermedium (AV septum).
    • The gap between the lower edge of septum primum and septum intermedium is called foramen primum.
    • As septum primum fuses with AV septum (septum intermedium), the upper part of septum primum breaks down.
    • The foramen thus formed is called foramen secundum (ostium secundum).
  • A second crescent-shaped septum now arises from the roof of primitive atrial chamber immediately to the right of septum primum. It is called septum secundum.
    • The septum secundum grows downward towards septum intermedium.
    • It overlaps the foramen secundum.
  • The right and left atria now communicate with each other through an oblique valvular passage between the upper margin of septum primum and lower margin of septum secundum. This passage is called foramen ovale.
  • So (option A) is correct answer.

Topic: The development of heart

Reference: Textbook of Clinical Embryology by Vishram Singh, 3rd Edition page Number - 240, 241

questions.text: Which of the following is most common type of tracheophageal fistula in the image given below?
questions.solution:
Tracheoesophageal fistula (TEF):

  • It is an abnormal communication between the trachea and esophagus.
  • This anomaly is often associated with esophageal atresia.
  • It occurs in 1 per 3000 to 4500 births.
  • The TEF occurs due to defective development of tracheoesophageal septum.
  • The tracheoesophageal folds fail to fuse with each other in a small segment, producing an abnormal communication between the trachea and esophagus the TEF.
  • The various types of TEF are:
    • Option A - Upper part of the esophagus ends in a blind pouch and lower part communicates with the trachea (85%) it's a TYPE - C TEF
    • As type above but the tracheoesophageal communication canal is replaced by a fibrous cord.
    • Option B - Both upper and lower parts of the esophagus communicates with the trachea by a common narrow canal. It is called H-shaped TEF (4%)
    • Option C - Upper part of the esophagus communicates with the trachea and lower end forms a blind pouch
    • Option D - Both upper and lower parts of the esophagus communicates with the trachea separately.
  • When milk or fluid is given to newborn infants with TEF, there occurs coughing and choking because milk or fluid enters into the respiratory tract. It may also lead to lung infection (pneumonia).

Topic: The development of respiratory system

Reference: Textbook of Clinical Embryology by Vishram Singh, 3rd Edition page Number - 217, 218

questions.text: All of the followings are an examples of the capillary shown in the figure below, EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Types of Capillaries:

  • There are two types of capillaries:
    • Continuous
    • Fenestrated (shown in the figure)
  • Continuous Capillaries:
    • Continuous capillaries are seen in the skin, connective tissue, muscle, lungs and brain (Option D).
  • Fenestrated Capillaries:
    • Fenestrated capillaries are seen in renal glomeruli (Option A), intestinal villi (Option B), endocrine glands and pancreas (Option C).

Topic: The histology of vessels

Reference: I. B. Singh's textbook of Human Histology, 10th Edition, Page Number - 122

questions.text: Which of the following layer is absent in the wall of gallbladder?
questions.solution:
The gallbladder:

  • Gallbladder is a muscular sac situated on the visceral surface of liver in the fossa for gallbladder.
  • The gallbladder stores and concentrates bile. This bile is discharged into the duodenum when required.
  • Submucosa (Option D) and goblet cells are absent in the gallbladder.
  • The wall of the gallbladder is made up of:
    • Mucosa: mucus membrane and lamina propria (Option B)
    • Fibromuscular coat (Option C)
    • Serosa/adventitia (Option A)
  • Mucous membrane:
    • The mucous membrane of the gall bladder is lined by a tall columnar epithelium with a striated border. The mucosa is highly folded. In sections, the folds may look like villi.
  • Fibromuscular coat:
    • The fibromuscular coat is made up mainly of connective tissue containing the usual elements.
    • Smooth muscle fibres are present and run in various directions.
  • Serosa/adventitia:
    • The serous layer has a lining of mesothelium resting on connective tissue.
    • The fundus and lower surface of body of gallbladder is covered by serosa, whereas the upper surface is attached to the fossa for gallbladder by means of connective tissue (adventitia).

Topic: The histology of GI tract

Reference: I. B. Singh's textbook of Human Histology, 10th Edition, Page Number - 201
